A 65-year-old avid male hiker, resident of Manali (at 5000 ft) was hiking in Sikkim with two companions. They hiked to Nathula in Sikkim at 12,000 ft in one day. He suddenly complained of extreme tiredness, light headedness, dizziness, difficulty in breathing. He began coughing and complained of tightness in the chest. He was taken to the emergency services of a local hospital. The examination revealed respiratory rate of 32 per min, heart rate of 125/min, bp 180/100 mm Hg, bluish discoloration of fingertips, crackles and wheeze on the right lower lobe. His X-ray chest was done and is shown:- Which of the following is not a possible reason for the man’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoxia induced vasoconstriction of pulmonary capillaries

options.label: B
options.text: Increased pressure in the pulmonary capillary beds

options.label: C
options.text: Disruption of the endothelial barrier resulting in leakage of fluid and proteins into the alveoli

options.label: D
options.text: Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

questions.correct_answer: D. Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

questions.text: There is a 38 year old female who presents to the OPD with pain and tingling in her right hand more so in the night time. Over the past several hours, the nursing staff reports that the patient has exhibited fluctuating periods of intermittent drowsiness and confusion where he has been speaking to non-existent visitors in his hospital room. She complains of severe acne and "spots" all over her face that have persisted for the last 8 years, despite innumerable creams and lotions. She reports spending several hours every morning using make-up just to go outside. She wishes to learn about cosmetic procedures or surgeries that could solve her problem. options.text: Gestational sac covered by endocervical glands

questions.text: A woman is getting 3 uterine contractions per 10 minutes. The fetus is in cephalic presentation and the head is not engaged. On vaginal examination, the cervical dilatation is 7 cm. The forehead, supra-orbital ridges and the bridge of the nose are felt. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. The pelvis is adequate. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Allow labour to continue without interference for 4 hours.

options.label: B
options.text: Carry out manual rotation of the head after full dilatation of the cervix.

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a caesarean section as soon as possible.

options.label: D
options.text: Perform an amniotomy and commence an oxytocin infusion.

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform a caesarean section as soon as possible.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not the indication of MgSO4 in obstetrics?

Which of the following is/are correct regarding progesterone? 1: It is used to prevent preterm labour in case of cervical shortening 2: It is used to treat preterm labour 3: It is used as emergency contraceptive 4: It is used to reverse endometrial hyperplasia without atypia
Identify the given placental abnormality:

A 32 years old G3P2L2 had a vaginal delivery at 39 weeks of gestation. During the third stage of labour, her pulse was found to be 40 per minute and she had hypotension. There was lengthening of cord and placenta was visible in vagina. On abdominal palpation, uterine fundus was not palpable. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not seen in MRKH syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Mood swings, hot flushes and other PMS symptoms

questions.text: A 16 years old girl had come with history of absence of menarche. Her height is 170cm, breast development is of TANNER stage 4 while axillary and pubic hair development is of TANNER 1. Which of the following should be the next step in investigations?
Which of the following complications is not associated with the given Mullerian anomaly?

A 28 years old P2L2 patient has a history of epilepsy since last 12 years. She is on anti-epileptic medications. She wants a suitable contraceptive. Which one of the following is not advisable in this case?

A 32 years old sexually active nulliparous patient has come with history of burning micturition with vaginal discharge since last 7 days. On examination, there are white flakes seen on vaginal epithelium. On removal of those flakes, there is severe inflammation seen in vagina. Her partner is not having any such symptom. What would be most likely found on wet mount examination?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal epithelial cells with irregular margins

options.label: D
options.text: Vaginal epithelial cells with inclusion bodies

questions.correct_answer: B. Spores and rods forming pseudo-hyphae

questions.text: Which tumour markers constitute “ROMA score” for ovarian malignancy?
questions.correct_answer: A. Ca-125 and human epidermal protein 4

questions.text: A 32 years old male has azoospermia. Which of the following tests would differentiate testicular azoospermia from pre-testicular azoospermia?
A 32 years old nulliparous patient had history of 3 abortions in last 3 years. All her abortions were spontaneous and were of 8-9 weeks. What is the possible cause amongst the following?

options.label: C
options.text: Balanced translocation in patient and partner

questions.correct_answer: C. Balanced translocation in patient and partner

questions.text: Recombinant HPV vaccine has which antigen
SRY region is located in?
questions.correct_answer: A. Short arm of Y chromosome

questions.text: A 38-year-old nulligravida patient presents with 2 years of infertility, dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. What would be the next step of management?
All are risk factors for vulvar cancer except
Asherman’s syndrome is most commonly associated with

A 17-year-old male with AIDS presents with worsening exertional dyspnea, fever, and a nonproductive cough. His temperature is 102 F, heart rate 120 beats/min, and respiratory rate 19. A physical exam reveals mild crackles and rhonchi bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. He has no known drug allergies. What is the best initial treatment?

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV levofloxacin

questions.correct_answer: C. Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole

questions.text: A 1-year old boy presents with a persistent cough for the past 5 days. He has had several episodes of pneumonia and upper respiratory infections since he was born. He also has several skin infections. He is in the 10th percentile for weight and 5th percentile for height, but at birth, he was in the 50th percentile. A dihydrorhodamine test is abnormal and peripheral blood smear does not indicate hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?

A 5-day-old female neonate is brought to the office in response to a call from the state laboratory reporting a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level higher than 200 mIU/L (normal <30 mIU/L) on her newborn screen. The neonate was born via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery at 40 weeks’ gestation with a birthweight of 3.5 kg. Her mother took levothyroxine for Hashimoto thyroiditis and prenatal vitamins during pregnancy. The neonate has been breastfeeding well on demand. Her vital signs are normal. She has mild jaundice and a small, reducible umbilical hernia. Her thyroid does not appear enlarged. The physical examination findings are otherwise normal. Confirmatory thyroid function tests show a TSH of 520 mIU/L (normal 0.6-5.6 mIU/L) and a free thyroxine of 0.5 ng/dL (6.4 pmol/L; normal 1.2-3.4 ng/dL [15.4-43.7 pmol/L]). Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate’s laboratory findings is

A 2-year-old boy's parents are concerned about significant speech delay. He exhibits unusual dysmorphology, including malar and zygomatic hypoplasia with downslanting palpebral fissures; prominent nose; significant micrognathia and retrognathia; small, posteriorly rotated, and malformed ears; and lower eyelid colobomas with absent eyelashes. His father has similar dysmorphology. Of the following, the MOST likely reason for this boy's speech delay is
Which of the following is the most common craniosynostosis involving a single suture?
A child with rickets did not respond to cholecalciferol. His serum calcium 10mg/dl, low phosphate and normal parathormone, which of the following is the diagnosis?
Which of the following is true about transplacental CMV infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Mothers who transmit are usually symptomatic

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common cause of non syndromic hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Diagnosed by persistent presence of IgM after 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: All babies are symptomatic at birth

questions.correct_answer: B. It is the most common cause of non syndromic hearing loss
